sent: The asteroid was discovered by American astronomer William Liller at Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile, on 23 January 1979, and named after Japanese astronomer Yoshihide Kozai.
1226 Golia was discovered on 22 April 1930, by Dutch astronomer Hendrik van Gent at Leiden Southern Station, annex to the Johannesburg Observatory in South Africa.
24827 Maryphil was discovered on 2 September 1995, by American astronomer Timothy Spahr at the Catalina Station near Tucson, Arizona, who named it for his parents, Mary & Phil Spahr.

The asteroid was discovered on 10 March 1988, by Japanese amateur astronomers Masaru Arai and Hiroshi Mori at Yorii Observatory (875) in central Japan.

367943 Duende was discovered by astronomers of the Astronomical Observatory of Mallorca at its robotic La Sagra Observatory in 2012, and named for the duende, a goblin-like creature from Iberian and Filipino mythology and folklore.

Discovered on 18 February 1874 by German-American astronomer Christian Peters at the Litchfield Observatory near Clinton, New York, 135 Hertha was named after the Teutonic and Scandinavian goddess of fertility, Hertha, also known as Nerthus.

The asteroid was discovered on 23 May 1998, by the LONEOS team at Anderson Mesa Station in Arizona, United States.

5201 Ferraz-Mello is an asteroid from the asteroid belt, discovered on 1 December 1983 by Ted Bowell at the Anderson Mesa Station of the Lowell Observatory.
144 Vibilia was discovered on 3 June 1875, by German-American astronomer Christian Peters at Litchfield Observatory of the Hamilton College in Clinton, New York, United States.

ISOHDFS 27 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Tucana, and was discovered in the Hubble Deep Field South survey.
NGC 965 is a spiral galaxy approximately 294 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation of Cetus.

NGC 327 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.

NGC 779 is a spiral galaxy seen edge-on, located in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 2915 is a blue dwarf galaxy located 12 million light-years away in the southern constellation Chamaeleon, right on the edge of the Local Group.
Messier 82 (also known as NGC 3034, Cigar Galaxy or M82) is a starburst galaxy approximately 12 million light-years away in the constellation Ursa Major.

NGC 167 is a spiral galaxy located approximately 172 million light-years from the Solar System in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 2715 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Camelopardalis.

UGC 8335 is about 400 million light-years from Earth, in the constellation Ursa Major.

NGC 3001 is a magnitude 11.83 spiral galaxy in the constellation Antlia, discovered on 30 March 1835 by John Herschel.
IC 342 (also known as Caldwell 5) is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation Camelopardalis, located relatively close to the Milky Way.
NGC 340 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 973 is a giant spiral galaxy located in the constellation Triangulum.
